seg.seg: May I have (trust thorough)ly [and] always in the good (or) bad act. [23b] May I seize the shame [and] modesty [that is] the one praised by the wise ones [and that is] dear to the good ones. [23c] May I always have the consciousness grown in moral behavior [and]

directed at the Law for long. 23. Through the writing of this excellent Śramaṇavarga may I recognize the thirst as a torment (kleśa). [24a] Again may I recognize the blame in the cauldron consisting in the clinging to let turn the birth[cycle]. [24b]
In connection with monkhood may I be able to tame the spirit [and] to make it pure. [24c] May I seize firmly [and] completely the rules pertaining to moral behavior; may my zeal not recede. 24.
Möchte ich die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens insgesamt fest erfassen; möchte mein Eifer nicht nachlassen!
May I grasp the rules of moral behaviour firmly; may my zeal never relent!
Das höchste [Ziel ist] das Gesetz, würdig [bzw. das Gesetz als das höchste [Ziel ist] würdig], von den drei Welten auf den Scheitel genommen zu werden [bzw. auf dem Scheitel getragen zu werden].
The highest [goal is] the law, worthy [or: the law as the highest [goal is] worthy] of being taken onto the crown of the head by the three worlds [or: of being worn on the crown of the head].

The Law as the supreme goal [is] worthy of being taken on the top of the three worlds. [25a] Through the writing of the excellent sun of the Mārgavarga may this path remain for a long time. [25b] In this way indeed may I make manifest the excellent eightfold
Durch das Schreiben der vortrefflichen Mārgavarga-Sonne möge dieser Pfad lange bestehen! Auf ebendiese Weise möchte ich den achtgliedrigen edlen Pfad [als] besten offenbar machen!
By writing the excellent Mārgavarga-sun, may this path persist [for] long! In exactly the same manner, may I make visible the eight-part noble path!

noble path. [25c] Through the seeing of the four truths may all obtain the pure eyes of wisdom. 25. I have written the Satkāravarga [understanding] this gain [and] pride (= Skt. lābha-satkāra-) as the e(nemy) of all the virtues. [26a]

He [= the enemy] tears out the skin of moral behavior [and] he cuts into small pieces the whole meat of wisdom. [26b] He breaks the bones of the energy [and] he cooks the marrow of meditation completely. [26c] Like the snake with sharp venom, even more than that,

may I avoid gain [and] pride. 26. Through the writing of the Drohavarga may my wish come true in the circle of all births. [27a] May I not feel anger towards an evil person, even an angry one, and even less
Durch das Schreiben des Drohavarga möge mir der Wunsch im Kreislauf aller Geburten in Erfüllung gehen: ...
By writing the Drohavarga, [this] wish may be fulfilled for me in the circle of all births: ...

towards good people. [27b] Even towards a murderous enemy may hate [and] enmity not reside in me at all [and] may I abandon the sin. [27c] May I not have a meeting with an ignorant one [and] may I come together with good people.
Mit einem Unwissenden möge mir nicht Zusammenkommen sein. Mit Guten möchte ich zusammenkommen!
With an ignorant one, may there be no meeting for me. May I meet with good ones!

27 Through the writing of the Smṛtivarga, this foundation of all virtues, may my wish come true. [28a] By consciousness directed towards the body may I understand all qualities [= dharma], each by its own mark. [28b] May I always
Durch das Schreiben des Smṛtivarga, dieser Grundlage aller Tugenden, möge mir der Wunsch in Erfüllung gehen: ...
By writing the Smṛtivarga, this foundation of all virtues, [this] wish may be fulfilled for me: ...

awake the good awakening having seized in the heart the three excellent jewels. [28c] May I not forget the observance, the wisdom, the meditation, without making harm. 28 (I have written) the Prakīrṇakavarga ...

p.note: The text has some colloquial spellings: cimpim for cämpim in a3, araṃśne for arañcne in b5, and degemination in śaiṣentso (a4) and ompalskoñe (b5). Whether sälyeṃno in a3 shows colloquial monophthongization or is simply an error for sälyaiṃno is difficult to judge. Since the text is metrical, forms with o mobile (or even preserved -ä as in wṣi-ñä in b 3) are often used.

The text has interesting spellings of virāma position: sometimes one has double marking with virama stroke and dot (e.g., pālaṣ[ä]\• in a 1); the chapter names xy-varga- > xy-vārgä borrowed from Sanskrit are never written with virama (even if the syllable is not counting metrically), which fits a more general writing habit also found in prose texts (cf. ). We also have virāma marking of the akālk-type with a small stroke between the la and the lower ka.
A complete leaf. It contains the Udānastotra in the longer version where the stanzas of the text proper are numbered 16 - 46 instead of 10 - 40.

Judging by the spelling (which is confirmed by both parallel texts), ykū-ime can only be a compound, to be more precise a pseudo-bahuvrihi 'having the consciousness of arriving'; it seems to be based on Skt. nityaṃ dharmagatā smṛtiḥ "always reflecting upon the Law" (attested in Uv. 15.10d and 13d) by a literal transposition of °gata- 'arriving' with the PPt yku ‘gone'.
The meter requires an additional syllable, which is the pronoun cau, judging from the parallel b5. Note the different version śīlne ausu in the parallel.
Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read [l](·)[k](·)[ñ](·) based on an autopsy of the original.

Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read [ai]sene based on an autopsy of the original. Note the variant verb fom karstoym in the parallel texts b 5 and b 6. Actually, both verbs make acceptable sense, but one should note that karsoym is effectivley attested in the next pāda.
At the end of the line there seems to be not enough space for the expected double dots.
In ynāmñe the second ligatura shows some kind of anusvāra sign above the ña, but ynāmñeṃ makes no sense.

Pace Lévi and Thomas, one has to read miyaṣly(·)e : [28] (–)[k]ī[rṇ](·) based on an autopsy of the original. There are no traces of ä-dots over the ya in miyaṣly(ñ)e. The form (although from the kausativ paradim) preserves A-character (cf. ).
